intro: Salix glaucophylla var. integra, commonly known as the smoothleaf willow, is a shrub native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its smooth, greyish-green leaves that are typically oval in shape. The plant produces catkins, which are cylindrical flower clusters, in the spring. It prefers moist, well-drained soils and is often found near streams or in wetlands. Its botanical features make it a valuable species for ecological restoration projects.
